image.altText: Black smoke plumes over a crash on the road with cars backed up.

items.synopsis: Police are urging motorists to avoid the the Bruce Highway following a multi-vehicle crash that has sparked several fires.

title.children: Six in hospital, military police at scene of fiery crash involving army vehicle in Queensland

image.altText: A red and white sign advertising a home for rent is erected in front of a small brick fence in front of a weatherboard house.

items.synopsis: Analysis from CoreLogic suggests Australia's rental market may see a reprieve from high rental growth next year as the Reserve Bank reaches the end of its latest interest rate hiking cycle.

title.children: Rising rents likely to ease next year as RBA signals the end of rate hikes

image.altText: a bald man in handcuffs flanked by two police detectives wearing suits and ties

items.synopsis: Michael Davidson Tillman was originally arrested in September 2010 and charged with attempted murder.

title.children: Convicted killer, once one of Australia's most wanted fugitives, pleads guilty to Gold Coast stabbing

image.altText: A man in a suit smile as he stands behind a micophone.

items.synopsis: All Indigenous students will be guaranteed a Commonwealth-supported place at the university of their choice, provided they meet entry criteria, as part of a set of reforms designed to make higher education more accessible for all Australians.

title.children: All Indigenous students guaranteed a funded university place as part of major education reforms

image.altText: Man in police uniform crossed arms standing next to pole

items.synopsis: A 61-year-old in Longreach has become Queensland Police's first Special Constable, a role created for retired officers who are still keen to patrol the streets.

title.children: 'Emu' the outback cop wanted to take it easy once he retired. Now he's returning to the service

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: The criminal trial into the White Island disaster has heard from volcano monitor GNS Science about how it changed its risk assessment process after a "near miss".

title.children: White Island trial hears of 'near miss' as expert gives evidence on volcano risk

image.altText: An aerial view of several large buildings and some car parks, with one building highlighted in red.

items.synopsis: A disability supporter provider has been able to buy back a property they previously owned for the bargain price of $1, thanks to the long memory of an employee.

title.children: For sale sign in front of old school sparks memory of legal agreement to buy it for $1

image.altText: A sign for Big W

items.synopsis: Yumi Stynes and Melissa Kang's sex education guide for teens is a topic of hot debate for its frankness. It also provides comprehensive, inclusive sex education that combats misinformation.

title.children: A teen sex ed book has been removed from Big W shelves to protect staff from abuse. This is what's actually inside

image.altText: A man dressed in an army uniform looks through gold binoculars next to a blue building.

items.synopsis: North Korea has stayed silent about the highly unusual entry of an American soldier across the heavily fortified border with South Korea. This is what we know so far and what has happened in the past.

title.children: What we know about the US soldier who 'willfully' crossed the border to North Korea

image.altText: Melisa Wu

items.synopsis: The day after Victoria dropped a sporting bombshell by pulling out of hosting the Commonwealth Games, there is still uncertainty about how the budget blew out so much and what the future holds for the Games.

title.children: Birmingham floated as possible Commonwealth Games host as fallout continues

image.altText: Donald Trump stands in front of a US flag

items.synopsis: For the third time this year, former US president Donald Trump has taken to social media to claim he's about to be charged in yet another criminal case. Here's what we know.

title.children: 'HORRIFYING NEWS': With a potential third arrest looming, Trump's legal situation just got worse

image.altText: Two elderly women and an elderly man raise their linked hands in celebration.

items.synopsis: They may be more comfortable sitting, but stubborn residents appear to have won another round in their stand-off with an aged-care provider on the NSW north coast.

title.children: Win for stubborn residents who refuse to leave in aged care home stand-off

image.altText: A woman in a winter coat and glasses.

items.synopsis: The lawyer for Raelene Polymiadis, who is accused of murdering her parents by injecting them with her own insulin, tells an Adelaide court her client's diabetes has been misdiagnosed by prison health authorities.

title.children: Woman accused of killing 94yo parents with insulin says prison authorities are mistreating her diabetes

image.altText: A white background has six different cards on it with various images angled for perspective. An FC logo is present.

items.synopsis: The Yes and No cases for the Voice to Parliament, drafted by parliamentarians from each side of the debate. Who kept their facts straight?

title.children: We fact checked some of the claims made by the Yes and No campaigns. Here's what we found

image.altText: A car next to a cricket pitch.

items.synopsis: A man who drove a stolen car through an Adelaide cricket game, with police in pursuit, is sentenced to up to six years in jail by a judge who said he had demonstrated "terrifying and wanton disregard" for public safety.

title.children: Axe-wielding driver who sped across cricket oval in stolen Holden gets six years in jail

image.altText: British Lions and Anzac XV opponents playing against each in 1989.

items.synopsis: For the first time in 36 years, the Lions will face a combined Australia-New Zealand team as part of a nine-match tour, which will also feature three Tests against the Wallabies.

title.children: Rugby Australia revives Anzac XV for 2025 British and Irish Lions tour

image.altText: Aerials drone pics of Howard Springs Quarantine Facility.

items.synopsis: Nearly half of the reports received by police were domestic violence related, authorities say, after hundreds of residents from remote communities were evacuated from their flood-ravaged homes in early March.

title.children: Police investigated 145 incidents involving Howard Springs flood evacuees, data reveals

image.altText: A portrait shot of a clean-shaven man with black hair, outdoors.

items.synopsis: The NSW Premier cited athlete accommodation as a main point of concern in the second day of ruling out hosting the competition.

title.children: Minns says he would have to 'tell thousands of people to get out of their homes' to host Commonwealth Games

image.altText: Razor wire at the top of a fence.

items.synopsis: Murderer Rodney Michael Cherry has served 20 years in jail, but still won't reveal the location of his stepdaughter's body. He killed the teen after killing his wife in central Queensland.

title.children: Double murderer's parole bid fails after no help finding stepdaughter's body

image.altText: A blonde woman in a blue suit

items.synopsis: The ex-girlfriend of Olympic boxer Harry Garside appears in a Sydney court over domestic violence allegations, with her lawyer saying she will plead not guilty and the case has a "troubling" history.

title.children: Court hears of 'troubling history' as ex-girlfriend of Harry Garside fronts court over domestic abuse charges

image.altText: Video shows the moments when Australian sailor Tim Shaddock was rescued.

items.synopsis: Australian man Timothy Shaddock says he and his adopted dog endured "many, many, many bad days" adrift in the Pacific surviving on fresh fish and rainwater.

title.children: Adrift for three months with his dog: The Australian sailor grateful to be alive after surviving on rainwater and fish

image.altText: Two police officers stand over a shoeless man in football shorts sitting handcuffed on the ground.

items.synopsis: Daniel John Hook, 37, has been charged over the death of a 39-year-old Aurukun man who was allegedly fatally stabbed at Railway Estate last week.

title.children: Second person charged over alleged stabbing murder in Townsville

image.altText: The back of a red Toyota Camry that is crushed to the point it's difficult to recognise it as a car, save for a license plate.

items.synopsis: Best friends Claire Sankey and Susi Kopysiewicz were killed when the car they were in veered off the Monaro Highway, crashing into two trees, in October last year.

title.children: Canberra teen who caused crash that killed two girls to be released from jail next October

image.altText: A sign beside a road outside Hakea Prison and Melaleuca Women's Prison.

items.synopsis: A prisoner has admitted killing child sex offender Ashley Bropho while he was locked up at a WA jail earlier this year.

title.children: Perth inmate pleads 'very guilty' to murdering sex offender who lured 9yo from park

image.altText: A sign reads Larni Barramal Yaluk Shrives Bridge with trees and shrubs behind

items.synopsis: A creek which was named after a derogatory term has regained its connection with Aboriginal language as part of a growing movement to reinstate traditional owner names.

title.children: Tears of joy as traditional owners celebrate end to creek's racist name

image.altText: Police and hazmat officials standing near a large canister on a beach.

items.synopsis: As authorities weigh up what to do with the large "foreign object", an expert says there is an increasing risk of space debris landing outside what's known as the "spacecraft cemetery".

title.children: As negotiations continue over WA's mystery rocket part, is this a sign of more space junk to come?

image.altText: A collage of one man and two women with a splattered watercolour effect in the background.

items.synopsis: Victoria and Western Australia were the first states to legalise voluntary assisted dying. As they prepare for mandatory reviews of their laws, it's renewed the debate about who should and shouldn't be allowed access.

title.children: 'Not dying quick enough': Christine's unknown prognosis means she can't access Voluntary Assisted Dying

image.altText: a woman in a t shirt saying 'warrior', resting her hand on a walking stick

items.synopsis: Only one per cent of rentals in Australia are affordable on the disability support pension, according to the disability royal commission. Add to that the need for accessibility, and the options are more scarce.

title.children: 'We just don't have choices': Priced out of her rental, Rachel may need to share a one-bedder with her adult daughter

image.altText: A man looks at stock prices through the window of the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market rises to its highest level in a month, while ASIC cancels the financial services licence of cryptocurrency firm FTX's local subsidiary. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises to four-week high, ASIC cancels crypto firm FTX's financial services licence

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Stock markets in the Asia-Pacific were mixed on Wednesday, with growth concerns dragging on China's market, while shares rose in Japan and Australia after healthy US company earnings and retail data bolstered hopes the world's biggest economy could avoid a recession. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 1.2%, and has been falling daily since China's weak economic growth data on Monday underscored the country's faltering pandemic recovery. Japan's Nikkei rose 0.9% and touched a two-week peak. Headline US retail sales data came in below forecasts, but core sales which exclude food, fuel and building materials, rose a solid 0.6% in June and had economists lifting gross domestic product (GDP) forecasts. Major US bank shares rose sharply on strong results, which drove Wall Street's industrial index, the Dow Jones, up 1.1% Shares of Microsoft surged 4%, adding $US100 billion in market value, after the company announced charges for artificial intelligence features in office software, a big first step in monetising AI's potential. Meanwhile, New Zealand inflation came in at 6% year-on-year (slower than a reading of 6.7% a month earlier), but above the market's expectations. Investors are now expecting NZ rates to stay higher for longer.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mixed performance across global markets

children.content: Stock markets in the Asia-Pacific were mixed on Wednesday, with growth concerns dragging on China's market, while shares rose in Japan and Australia after healthy US company earnings and retail data bolstered hopes the world's biggest economy could avoid a recession.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 1.2%, and has been falling daily since China's weak economic growth data on Monday underscored the country's faltering pandemic recovery.
Japan's Nikkei rose 0.9% and touched a two-week peak.

Headline US retail sales data came in below forecasts, but core sales which exclude food, fuel and building materials, rose a solid 0.6% in June and had economists lifting gross domestic product (GDP) forecasts.
Major US bank shares rose sharply on strong results, which drove Wall Street's industrial index, the Dow Jones, up 1.1%

Shares of Microsoft surged 4%, adding $US100 billion in market value, after the company announced charges for artificial intelligence features in office software, a big first step in monetising AI's potential.

Meanwhile, New Zealand inflation came in at 6% year-on-year (slower than a reading of 6.7% a month earlier), but above the market's expectations. Investors are now expecting NZ rates to stay higher for longer.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mining giant Rio Tinto has flagged concerns about a global economic slowdown as it logged a raft of production issues across its operations but said its iron ore production should be at the upper end of its expectations for the year. Prices of iron ore, from which Rio Tinto derives around 70% of its profits, eased over the second quarter on concerns over China's debt-ridden property sector, but could improve after Beijing on Tuesday pledged to roll out policies to boost growth. "China's economic recovery has fallen short of initial market expectations, as the property market downturn continues to weigh on the economy and consumers remain cautious despite monetary policy easing," Rio Tinto said in its quarterly report. "Manufacturing data in advanced economies showed a further slowdown and recessionary risks remain." The miner recorded a small miss on its second-quarter iron ore shipments on Wednesday, hurt by a train derailment during the quarter, but said it was on track for full-year shipments in the upper half of its forecast range (320 million to 335 million metric tons).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rio Tinto warns on global slowdown risks, production issues

children.content: Mining giant Rio Tinto has flagged concerns about a global economic slowdown as it logged a raft of production issues across its operations but said its iron ore production should be at the upper end of its expectations for the year.

Prices of iron ore, from which Rio Tinto derives around 70% of its profits, eased over the second quarter on concerns over China's debt-ridden property sector, but could improve after Beijing on Tuesday pledged to roll out policies to boost growth.

"China's economic recovery has fallen short of initial market expectations, as the property market downturn continues to weigh on the economy and consumers remain cautious despite monetary policy easing," Rio Tinto said in its quarterly report.
"Manufacturing data in advanced economies showed a further slowdown and recessionary risks remain."

The miner recorded a small miss on its second-quarter iron ore shipments on Wednesday, hurt by a train derailment during the quarter, but said it was on track for full-year shipments in the upper half of its forecast range (320 million to 335 million metric tons).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The corporate regulator has cancelled the financial services licence of cryptocurrency firm FTX's local subsidiary, effective from July 14. Last November, the Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC) had suspended the license until May, taking back its permit to deal in derivative and foreign exchange contracts to retail and wholesale clients. Bahamas-headquartered FTX, once a rising star of the crypto industry with a $US32 billion valuation in January 2023 filed for US bankrupty protection in November, saying it was unable to completely repay customers who had deposited funds on its exchange. Its founder Sam Bankman-Fried is facing numerous criminal fraud charges in the US courts. The terms of the cancellation include provisions that until the end of July 12 next year, FTX Australia may provide limited financial services that relate to the termination of existing derivatives with clients, ASIC said. If you're wondering what's happening with Mr Bankman-Fried's trial, here's the latest:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIC cancels FTX Australia's financial services licence

featuredLink.title: 'A rush to judgement': FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried urges court to toss charges

children.content: The corporate regulator has cancelled the financial services licence of cryptocurrency firm FTX's local subsidiary, effective from July 14.
Last November, the Australian Securities
Investments Commission (ASIC) had suspended
the license until May, taking back its permit to deal in derivative and foreign exchange contracts to retail and wholesale clients.

Bahamas-headquartered FTX, once a rising star of the crypto industry with a $US32 billion valuation in January 2023 filed for US bankrupty protection in November, saying it was unable to completely repay customers who had deposited funds on its exchange.
Its founder Sam Bankman-Fried is facing numerous criminal fraud charges in the US courts.

The terms of the cancellation include provisions that until the end of July 12 next year, FTX Australia may provide limited financial services that relate to the termination of existing derivatives with clients, ASIC said.
If you're wondering what's happening with Mr Bankman-Fried's trial, here's the latest:

image.altText: A young man jumping rope.

items.synopsis: Tom Norman is competing with his family at the World Jump Rope Championships in the United States. But he hopes skipping will eventually be made an Olympic sport.

title.children: Thought skipping was just for kids? This niche sport could one day be an Olympic event

image.altText: ottles of Johnson & Johnson baby powder line a drugstore shelf.

items.synopsis: Johnson & Johnson must pay $US18.8 million ($27.6 million) to a California man who said he developed cancer from exposure to its baby powder, a US jury has decided.

title.children: J&J ordered to pay $27.6 million to man who says he got cancer from their baby powder

image.altText: A man wearing glasses holds up an iPhone in his hand.

items.synopsis: A first-generation iPhone sells for almost 380 times its original price of $US499 ($735)  when it first went on sale in 2007.

title.children: First-generation iPhone sells for almost $280,000 at auction
